comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
OK.  The link behind "some Ambulance Corps info" once again is timed out.  This seems to be a common problem with links to a variety of online databases.  For example, you cannot link to anything in the Australian War Memorial collection, or the National Archives of Australia online collection without the link timing out.

Until an insider tells you the work around trick for those two insitutions' online collections, that is.

I did as you suggested and used the Agency search with "Ambulance Corps" and found plenty of useful information.

Thank you.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: alcodude it could be Woolloomooloo Wharf or the Randwick Military Hospital. All we have to go on is the original caption which says "Ambulance Trams - used to convey wounded military personnel from Woolloomooloo Wharf to Randwick Military Hospital". Perhaps one of our Flickr friends might know more?

comment.author: 34536224@N05
comment._content:
Photo was taken at the Randwick Tramway Workshops. Everything looks very fresh - just after the Cs 31 and 44 ? were converted?

I have been trawling the various historic photos for several years looking for a Woolloomooloo tram somewhere on the line. The closest I've got is a distant glimpse of an N class, stuck in what was then Haig Ave, waiting for a procession in College St to finish and a few College St shots of the track and wiring branching off into Haig Avenue.

comment.author: 35607158@N06
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Science, Technology, History, and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 34536224@N05
comment._content:
There is a tiny fragment left of the tram line which branched from Belmore Rd (Coogee line) into the (then) Randwick Military Hospital (originally a state orphanage and now part of Prince of Wales Hospital.

The edge of the tram section in the middle of the road was made with a strip (how deep I don't know) of stone. The edgings still exist in Belmore Rd Randwick. At the High St intersection, a small branch strip is still present. (west side of Belmore Rd at the High / Avoca Sts intersection).
